posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
First off, I couldn’t find a modern version of this question, so I am sorry if it is redundant.

After seeing 1690’s use of a pneumatic cylinder to produce a vacuum, it got me thinking about modern rules and what is allowed.

A device used to produce a vacuum is not a pneumatic system requiring all the compressors and whatnot. But would a system that just has two cylinders linked by tubing, and one of them has its shaft actuated by a motor, causing the second to extend/retract, be considered a pneumatic system?

Asking because a pneumatic locking system would be nice to have, but not if we need to load on 5 pounds of equipment that wouldn’t even be used.

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked: As an RI I would call a Pneumatic system, any set of components built/assembled by the team that can permanently hold compressed air.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: That’s how I read it, too. But thought I’d check. Thank you!

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked: I think it depends on the exact use case. If you set it up with a retracted cylinder connected to a motor, and an extended cylinder at the other end of the tubing, and you plan to only operate it in one direction, it should fall under the exception in R804 blue box A. as it will only create a vacuum and will never compress the air inside above atmospheric pressure.

posts.name: Michael Cameron
posts.cooked:
Drakxii:

that can permanently hold compressed air

My understanding is that the system, and others before it, do NOT compress air and hold it. The “backside” of the pistons technically compress air while pulling a vacuum but are very likely fully open to the atmosphere via their exhaust ports.

All of the rules managing compressed air risks do not apply.

(edit) and if they are clever with shuttle valves, they could be drawing a vacuum in both directions and exhausting the unwanted “compressed” air continuously, I suppose.

posts.name: bobbysq
posts.cooked: Would a solenoid or linear actuator do the job? I feel like those could be as effective while being less of a grey area in the rules.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
Zaque:

If you set it up with a retracted cylinder connected to a motor, and an extended cylinder at the other end of the tubing, and you plan to only operate it in one direction, it should fall under the exception in R804 blue box A

So a possible work around would be this: Highlighted is atmospheric air enclosed in system. Pull on longer cylinder, produce vacuum force to draw air from pancake (there’d be two), moving it’s piston out. Only run it one way and it is only producing a vacuum.

bobbysq:

Would a solenoid or linear actuator do the job?

Yes. But we do not have a linear motorized actuator, or legal solenoid, on hand.

posts.name: Jeremiah Johnson
posts.cooked:
You could simplify this by pushing or pulling the rod end of a single-acting spring return/extension cylinder. On a spring return single acting single rod cylinder, for example, when the rod is pulled the pressure port will generate suction. This will circumvent any question of storing compressed air as both ports will be vented to atmosphere until the pressure port is plugged.

My drawing has a label of using a linear actuator, but any method of applying a sufficient axial force to the rod would work.
